repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_data.diff_hunk:

comment_data.body: now using `%N` in a statusline becames a hard error. is this intentional? The alternative (what vim `-printer` does) is to change this to `num = 0`
I didn't put much thought into it. I guess it would be safer to just return 0, assuming anyone even uses this.

This is a case where passive voice is making things less obvious than necessary.
```suggestion
  `:hardcopy` was removed. Instead, use `:TOhtml` and print the resulting HTML using a web browser or some other HTML viewer.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -732,5 +739,10 @@ Cscope:
                                                                       *cscope*
   Cscope support has been removed in favour of LSP based solutions.
 
+Hardcopy:
+                                                                     *hardcopy*
+  `:hardcopy` has been removed in favour of using `:TOhtml` and printing via
+  an external process.

@@ -732,5 +739,9 @@ Cscope:
                                                                       *cscope*
   Cscope support has been removed in favour of LSP based solutions.
 
+Hardcopy:
+                                                                     *hardcopy*
+  `:hardcopy` was removed. Instead, use `:TOhtml` and print the resulting HTML using a web browser or some other HTML viewer.

comment_regular_data.body:
- Make `has('printer')` return 0
- Make `has('postscript')` return 0
- Make `vim-patch.sh` remove the removed the files

missing some print-related option handling in `option.c` (line 290ff)

there's also a reference to `printfont` in `optwin.vim`
I don't think your last commit removed translations properly. You didn't remove the comment above them, and for some fuzzy `msgstr` you didn't even remove `msgid`.

my comment from last time... https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/15235#issuecomment-899482316 : 

> It's a niche feature, but has not been a noticeable burden to keep around. Except hardcopy.c does get flagged by static analysis, that's a cost.
> 
> If we can ship or point to a plugin that addresses the basic use-case, then we should rip out hardcopy. There is no reason for a bunch of builtin options for this. 
> 
> The main features needed AFAICT, are:
> 
> 1. get a full "rendered" document
>     - the `:TOhtml` plugin already demonstrates the mechanics of this (potentially improved by treesitter)
> 2. send it to the system printer
>     - does the Nvim API need a `hardcopy` event that UIs could handle?

Perhaps we could alias `:hardcopy` to TOHtml or something like that. We should try to have a reasonable answer to address the `:hardcopy` use-case, some sort of minimal plugin that outputs HTML or PDF, etc.

> I don't think your last commit removed translations properly. You didn't remove the comment above them, and for some fuzzy `msgstr` you didn't even remove `msgid`.

I removed them via `sed`. Cleaned them up now. Need to review them by hand.

> Perhaps we could alias :hardcopy to TOHtml or something like that. We should try to have a reasonable answer to address the :hardcopy use-case, some sort of minimal plugin that outputs HTML or PDF, etc.

The main issue is that `:hardcopy` behaves completely differently on Windows so I don't know what reasonable alias we could add.

For reference, the default value for `printexpr` (on unix) is:

```vim
    system(['lpr']
           + (empty(&printdevice)?[]:['-P', &printdevice])
           + [v:fname_in])
    .. delete(v:fname_in)
    + v:shell_error
```

So we could do something like:

```lua
    local postscript_tmp = convert_to_postscript(bufnr)
    vim.fn.system({'lpr', postscript_tmp})
    vim.fn.delete(postscript_tmp)
    if vim.v.shell_error then
       error(vim.v.shell_error)
    end
```

Also we can't easily alias `:hardcopy` since it begins with a lowercase char, unless we implement the alias directly in C.

The use case is so niche I'm not sure if it would be worth it instead of just suggesting to use `:TOhtml` and a browser.

Aliasing commands like that will age badly I think. Doing that will implicitly encode historical details that is gonna be annoying to explain. "Oh, in vim hardcopy prints out a file. In neovim, hardcopy is aliased to tohtml because this and this and that...". Finding information about hardcopy online is gonna be annoying as well, because confusions of the nature "do you mean vim hardcopy or neovim hardcopy?" will show up.
Agreed; better to provide a new (plugin) command `:Print`.
`:Print` may also cause confusion because it is equivalent to `:print` in Vim and Vi.

> Perhaps we could alias :hardcopy to TOHtml or something like that. We should try to have a reasonable answer to address the :hardcopy use-case, some sort of minimal plugin that outputs HTML or PDF, etc.

I think everyone is agreed that we want a rewrite of the `TOHtml` plugin that also handles extmarks, and that that would address the biggest chunk of use cases here.

The big question is: does that need to happen **before** the excision?  Arguably, `:hardcopy` is already broken right now as it doesn't work with treesitter or LSP semantic tokens (or any kind of extmark); seeing just how much code and docs is affected here further tilts my opinion in favor of removal.

(Whether and how to wrap `:TOHtml` into a cross-platform one-stop-print-shop is another question that can be tackled after these two steps.)

> The big question is: does that need to happen before the excision? Arguably, :hardcopy is already broken right now as it doesn't work with treesitter or LSP semantic tokens (or any kind of extmark); seeing just how much code and docs is affected here further tilts my opinion in favor of removal.

Let's nix it already. it is one legacy file less to be affected when doing general code refactors/quality improvements.
What is the point of removing this from menu.vim and optwin.vim then?
The possibility of users hitting errors when leaving it in?
They are already guarded by `has('printer')`.
Then we can just as well remove them.
Let's get some reviews so we can make a decision. I've just had to resolve a conflict so that file is getting churn.

Do I understand correctly that the current fallback for those of us who used this feature is to now instead use `:TOhtml` and a browser? I personally don't like this, as it adds an extra step, but I can see the value of simplifying and I can agree with the idea that this feature would be better implemented as a plugin.

That's exactly the case.

- Most users didn't even know this existed
- of those that did,[ very few ever used it](https://twitter.com/Neovim/status/1433525597821562889)
- It didn't behave consistently across platforms
- It doesn't work with extmarks/treesiter highlights (just `:syntax`)

so the scales tipped pretty heavily to removing it.

If anyone creates a plugin for printer support, we would happily endorse it (providing it's good and works).

> now instead use `:TOhtml` and a browser?

I'm in favor of adding some builtin sugar that saves steps here. 

- https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/21629
    1. generates HTML
    2. saves the file to reasonable place (~/Downloads or `stdpath('run')` ?)
    3. opens the HTML in system web browser

Then you just hit ctrl-p to print, is that good enough? Step (2) above is the annoying part--finding and opening the file.

> That's exactly the case.  so the scales tipped pretty heavily to removing it.

No objections from me, except the remark that this means, as one of the few users, that I will need to change my workflow. No big deal - I don't print things often anyway.

> > now instead use `:TOhtml` and a browser?
> 
> I'm in favor of adding some builtin sugar that saves steps here. E.g. we could ship a `:Hardcopy` command  , is that good enough?

Yes, for me it seems like a convenient fallback solution that I would be happy to use.

I also use this. I'm not mad that it's been removed given the issues with tree sitter though; I have a hack script to turn it off temporarily, change colour scheme, etc to print, but this is a hack. The correct solution is some plugin rendering html then using a (possibly headless) web browser to generate a PDF. 

For my limited use cases I'll just use vim for it or something like https://github.com/matze/tree-painter

Am I right that the plan was to write a plugin to replace this, but that doesnt exist yet, and the feature has been deleted anyway?

(Yes, I use it; no, I didnt see nor reply to a random twitter poll)

> Am I right that the plan was to write a plugin to replace this, but that doesnt exist yet, and the feature has been deleted anyway?

Yes.

Thank you for clarifying. Honestly I can most likely live without hardcopy these days. But it does make me wonder what other features I rely on might suddenly disappear. I need to rethink getting invested.
If you rely on a feature, you can always keep using the last version that still has it.
The path forward for hardcopy is https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/21629
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/27097 adds treesitter (and more) support to `:TOhtml`, which opens the door for  `:Hardcopy`.
